title: 103_hr599
content: The Act may be cited as the "Solid Waste Compact Act of 1993" and includes an amendment to the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act. The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act is amended to define terms related to compacts, compact commissions, compact regions, solid waste disposal, and non-sited compact regions. The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act is amended to define terms related to regional disposal facilities, solid waste, and states' responsibilities for waste disposal. The Solid Waste Compact Act of 1993 requires states to submit waste disposal plans to the EPA within 12 months. States can enter into regional compacts for solid waste disposal to manage responsibilities effectively. Federal law is not affected by these compacts. The Solid Waste Compact Act of 1993 mandates states to submit waste disposal plans to the EPA within 12 months. Regional compacts for solid waste disposal do not grant new authority to regulate in a way conflicting with EPA or DOT regulations, or to regulate health, safety, or environmental hazards. Federal law remains applicable and unaffected by these compacts. The Solid Waste Compact Act of 1993 allows states to restrict the use of regional waste disposal facilities, subject to Congressional consent every 5 years. The Act does not affect State law, and alternative waste disposal methods must be submitted within 12 months of enactment. The Solid Waste Compact Act of 1993 allows states to restrict regional waste disposal facilities with Congressional consent every 5 years. The Environmental Protection Agency will identify alternative waste management programs and provide technical guidance within 24 months of the Act's enactment. The Environmental Protection Agency will identify alternative waste management programs within 24 months of the Solid Waste Compact Act of 1993, if pursued as an alternative to traditional solid waste management.
